lead_paragraph: The law in North Carolina requires voters to produce one of six types of identification, but opponents, including the Justice Department, say it suppresses votes.

byline.original: By ALAN BLINDER and KEN OTTERBOURG

headline.print_headline: Election Practices at Stake in North Carolina as Voter ID Law Trial Begins
headline.main: Arguments Over North Carolina Voter ID Law Begin in Federal Court

snippet: The law in North Carolina requires voters to produce one of six types of identification, but opponents, including the Justice Department, say it suppresses votes.
abstract: Federal civil trial begins over North Carolina's voter identification law, which requires voters to produce one of six accepted credentials or to submit provisional ballot; supporters say requirements safeguard against potential fraud; opponents of law, including Justice Dept, cite parts of Voting Rights Act in arguing against it, saying law suppresses voices of black and Hispanic voters.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
